guide.conclusion: With some creativity and some junk, you can quickly make custom faucet covers that fit your faucet better than the cheap ones available at your local hardware store.

guide.introduction: It's rare to get very low temperatures where I live, but last winter the temperature was low enough to freeze and burst pipes. After thawing my pipes, I needed outdoor faucet covers fast, but the hardware store was sold out. With an empty drink mix container as the base, I was able to make comparable faucet covers from items I had around the house. It takes about 10 minutes to make each cover.
guide.introduction_rendered:
It's rare to get very low temperatures where I live, but last winter the temperature was low enough to freeze and burst pipes. After thawing my pipes, I needed outdoor faucet covers fast, but the hardware store was sold out. With an empty drink mix container as the base, I was able to make comparable faucet covers from items I had around the house. It takes about 10 minutes to make each cover.

Relevant parts
  • small roll of thin fiberglass insulation
  • 2' metal wire or coat hanger
  • 4'' diameter round plastic container
Tools
  • 1/4'' drill bit
  • Gloves
  • Scissors
  • Wire cutter/stripper
  • hand-held electric drill

parts.text: small roll of thin fiberglass insulation

lines.text: For tools, you will need scissors, gloves, wire cutters, and an electric drill with a 1/4" drill bit. Beer is optional.
lines.text_raw: For tools, you will need scissors, gloves, wire cutters, and an electric drill with a 1/4" drill bit. Beer is optional.

lines.text: For materials, you will need a large diameter plastic container, in this case I had an empty Gatorade can. I picked up a $5 roll of fiberglass pipe insulation from the hardware store, and had a roll of fence wire on hand. Also, you will need several feet of duct tape or similar waterproof tape.
lines.text_raw: For materials, you will need a large diameter plastic container, in this case I had an empty Gatorade can. I picked up a $5 roll of fiberglass pipe insulation from the hardware store, and had a roll of fence wire on hand. Also, you will need several feet of duct tape or similar waterproof tape.

lines.text: In a pinch, you could substitute cloth for the batting, such as a pair of worn socks, and use a straightened coat hanger for the wire.
lines.text_raw: In a pinch, you could substitute cloth for the batting, such as a pair of worn socks, and use a straightened coat hanger for the wire.

lines.text: Using a drill, bore a 1/4" hole in the bottom of the plastic jug near the side.
lines.text_raw: Using a drill, bore a 1/4" hole in the bottom of the plastic jug near the side.

lines.text: Cut a 2' length of wire with wire cutters.
lines.text_raw: Cut a 2' length of wire with wire cutters.

lines.text: Fold wire in half with a tight bend, and insert the bent end into the hole from the bottom. This wire will secure the cover to the faucet body.
lines.text_raw: Fold wire in half with a tight bend, and insert the bent end into the hole from the bottom. This wire will secure the cover to the faucet body.

lines.text: With your gloves on, cut several strips of insulation, a short strip 6" long and two longer strips 12" long.
lines.text_raw: With your gloves on, cut several strips of insulation, a short strip 6" long and two longer strips 12" long.

lines.text: The short strip will insulate the bottom of the jug and the longer strips will insulate the inside and create an air seal around the faucet head.
lines.text_raw: The short strip will insulate the bottom of the jug and the longer strips will insulate the inside and create an air seal around the faucet head.

lines.text: Fold the small length of insulation and stuff into the bottom of the jug.
lines.text_raw: Fold the small length of insulation and stuff into the bottom of the jug.

lines.text: Wrap one of the longer lengths of insulation around the inside bottom, and another around the inside top, protruding about an inch past the jug lid.
lines.text_raw: Wrap one of the longer lengths of insulation around the inside bottom, and another around the inside top, protruding about an inch past the jug lid.

lines.text: The folded wire sticks out past the jug lid another 4" or so, in order to make it easy to loop around the faucet head later.
lines.text_raw: The folded wire sticks out past the jug lid another 4" or so, in order to make it easy to loop around the faucet head later.

lines.text: Wrap duct tape around the outside of the jug, and around the protruding insulation to protect it from getting wet.
lines.text_raw: Wrap duct tape around the outside of the jug, and around the protruding insulation to protect it from getting wet.

lines.text: To install on a faucet head (pictured), loop the folded wire around part of the faucet and push the jug against the faucet, pulling excess wire through the back.
lines.text_raw: To install on a faucet head (pictured), loop the folded wire around part of the faucet and push the jug against the faucet, pulling excess wire through the back.

lines.text: Take the two wire ends sticking out, and fold around opposite sides of the jug, meeting at the top side.
lines.text_raw: Take the two wire ends sticking out, and fold around opposite sides of the jug, meeting at the top side.

lines.text: Twist wires together where they meet, and secure your faucet cover.
lines.text_raw: Twist wires together where they meet, and secure your faucet cover.

lines.text: Optionally paint cover to match your house if you don't like the chic look of duct-taped junk.
lines.text_raw: Optionally paint cover to match your house if you don't like the chic look of duct-taped junk.

guide.summary: Make a custom garden-faucet cover from common household items.
